response.answer_text: Disclaimer: the following game does not contain blood, gore, sex, jumpscares, ghosts or any other profanity. Actually, It is not strictly necessary to have the mentioned things to make something disturbing.  Bully/ Canis Canem Edit  Probably the boldest move from Rockstar Games to tackle the school system, bullying and society in general. This is probably one of the most controversial games ever created who got all the Soccer Moms, Karens and “lovely” people like good ol’ Jack Thompson a bit edgy. The game was released back in 2006 with several future ports and remasters, but seriously watered down thanks to controversies. The game was intended to be far more aggresive, by including: Blood, Bruises, foul language, being able to bully girls (you can do it via glitch), girls bullying each other like boys do and making Jimmy (the main character) an actual bully. Despite being tamed, fortunately the core message remained intact. Why is disturbing? 1- “Canis canem edit”: That phrase means “dog eat dog” and is basically the motto of this game, whose definition is: “ruthless and fierce competition”. In Bullworth (the school where the game occurs) we have cliques and each clique fiercefully assert dominance on each other. The order: Jocks (the kings of the school)GreasersPreppies (Despite having money and pretty much controlling school with it, Greasers have an upper hand in hierarchy since they’re far more savage and can beat most preppies in fights)Bullies (if it wasn’t for Russel, the strongest student, bullies would be bullied by upper cliques. They’re the scavengers)Non Clique/Regular studentsNerds (The guys with the best grades but at the very bottom of the hierarchy by being weak and overall extremely unpopular)Everyone picks on everyone, everyone is in a constant “competitively aggresive” state by crushing the weak students and humilliating others and the tormentor gains status by showing strengh and dominance over others. To take things farther, outside school, bullying is a big thing. We got people from the rich side of the town humilliating and mocking on blue collar workers and homeless people. We also got bullying between teachers with Mr Hattrick (Math) bullying on Mr Galloway (English) and even we got teachers blatantly promoting bullying like Mr Burton (Gym) The disturbing part? this is how real world works. We are constantly competing on each other, humans are in a constant state of conflict, humans are warmongers by nature. We need to compete, we need to crush and dominate on those who are weaker and those who will threaten our position, dominance will make people follow you, we need to prove we are superior than others. “It's America! We go in there with threats and bribes until we get what we want. If all else fails, we beat the crap out of everyone” - Jimmy Hopkins.  2- Transgression is Problematic: People love to think that Jimmy Hopkins is some kind of White Knight that allows the player to insert themselves in a “revenge of the nerds” fantasy, by beating up Jocks and Cool Kids. The truth is… Jimmy is a victim from the begining to the end of the game. Not only because people pick on him, but for standing for himself and for those who can’t stand for themselves. Jimmy gets in trouble for defending himself from bullies and Principal Crabblesnitch appoints that behavior as “problematic” labeling him as a “pugilistic” I will talk about the Townies/Dropouts, the strongest clique and maybe the most interesting.  These ruthless misfits that dropped out school and some of them couldn’t attend it, are actually a product of the system. They couldn’t thrive in a system that didn’t gave them any chance to improve and have a different mindset, they feel a deep hatred to a society who marginalized them and have a vendetta against those who can afford an education and the education that neglected them. Zoe, a Townie and one of Jimmy’s girlfriends. Was sexually harassed by Mr Burton (Gym) She stood for herself and denounced him. What happened? she got expelled. The disturbing part? Don’t you see the pattern here? In school when you defend yourself against a bully, you will get suspended. The system does not reward those who can stand for themselves. That is transgression and that is problematic. Clean your noses…  Now leaving aside my “anti-system” rant, there are some other things quite disturbing: 3- Everyone is on medication: There is a roaming animation in particular that shows both kids and adults taking pills. Also, most people in this game claim to be on medication and being on therapy. Since Bullworth is a small and conformist town, could be a reference on how people’s mindset is conditionated. 4- Happy Volts Asylum: We are going to the dark corners of this game. This place is creepy as hell, you have to go there twice to rescue Mr Galloway and Johnny Vincent. To make things worst, people there are under inhuman treatment/experiments and you can hear screams from the interns. The patients are townies. 5- Mihailovich:  This guy is the “In and Out” Motel owner. Happens that this guy is a serial killer who awaits for people to take a room or kidnaps people and takes them to one room to murder them. You can hear screams outside of the hotel at night time. What boggles me is the fact that Bullies and Greasers hangs in the hotel... NEAR a serial killer! The funny part? You can humilliate the serial killer and will run away like nothing. 6- Preppies are a bunch of Inbreds Preppies in this game are known for their incestuous practices. Actually Derby (preps leader) is betrothed with his cousin Pinky (one of your GFs) Tad Spencer, one of the preppies, claims to have webbed toes because he’s inbred. He also has a brother with no chin in Happy Volts Asylum. 7- Speaking of Tad Spencer…  The backstory of this guy is downright disturbing. He has a beyond abusive father that hits both him and his mother. He truly fears him and even claims that his father taught him the meaning of pain. His father once stabbed him with a fork after Tad made a birthday cake for him. He takes social status very seriously, a behavior mostly encouraged by his father, who tells him to take the leadership of the preppies clique by humilliating Derby, his leader. Some of his quotes: “Now calm down, Dad. Calm down” - (While wandering around)“No Daddy. Stop. Stop”“Why Daddy? Why?”“I'm sorry, Daddy. I'm sorry.”“Please, Daddy. Don't hit me anymore.”“I'll do better next time, Dad. I promise.”“Don't punish me, Daddy. Please.”8- Eunice and Beatrice: Oh boy, the two “lovely” ladies.  First we got Eunice, an umbearably ugly girl who is mercilessly bullied and is actually the first girl who can make out with. Self explanatory.  ____  By the other hand we got Beatrice. Another unattractive girl who is mercilessly bullied by Mandy the cheerleader and most girls and boys from school. People love to think that Beatrice is a noble damsel in distress who is tormented by cool kids and Mandy. Yes, Beatrice is a victim at certain extent, but she’s just as nasty as Mandy. The problem? Her condition of unpopular girl makes her go under the radar, deceiving people in process. She’s actually self entitled, has good grades but dumb in everything else, whinny and she’s the most aggresive of the nerds alongside Donald and Thad (she’s prone to pick on others and shove bullies until some of them smack her down) Mandy comes with straight humilliation while Beatrice is the manipulative one. Beatrice takes advantage of Jimmy by blackmailing him to tell other girls and authorities that he’s a sexual pervert in order to make him retrieve her homework stolen from Mandy. She also manipulates him to get her confiscated diary because she wrote romantic suff between both and made him kiss her twice. The disturbing part? She has herpes, HERPES. and you have to kiss her TWICE! That’s fucked up! (that image above does not show it since bully has both models, one for cutscenes and one for gameplay And the later one does not show it)  Thank god her portrait is not main storyline mission. 9- Gary Smith:  The main villain, This guy is a straight up sociopath and narcissist. Think on him as some kind of a Joker, he’s an agent of chaos, loves to torture people (specially nerds) and manipulate cliques to instigate fights among them, for no apparent reason. He’s medicated and his therapist (like other students) is affraid of him. He has a poor concept of what is right and what is wrong and plans to take school. When he achieves his goal, takes principal as a hostage and turns school into a battlefield, making people fight each other. The sole reason of being a sociopath is disturbing enough. He gets in your mind, manipulate others against you or each other, he is the epitome of psychological abuse. Traumas? abuse? Insecurities? he does what he does because he can. He’s the ultimate definition of a bully. 10- Mr Burton:  Gym teacher and athlete in decadence in his 50’s. The guy is ruthless towards students and promotes bullying because according to him “it builds character” This guy has a particular taste: smell girls’s panties. There is a mission called “Panty Raid” where he tells Jimmy to sneak into girls dorm, take girls’s panties and retrieve them to him. This guy also has a thing for teenage girls, there is a quote who implies that he is trying to get into Mandy. He also sexually harassed Zoe. I think we could call him “pedophile”. 11- Edna the cook lady  She has to be one of the most hideous characters of all the game. She is known for contaminating food, hunting stray cats and Ms Phillips’s (Art and Photography) cats to serve them for lunch, serving rotten meat and being even uglier than Eunice. Keep reading… Edna has a crush on Dr Watts (Chemistry) and asks Jimmy to arrange a date and keep the other students away in order to not spoil the date. Edna drugs Dr Watts and drags him to a motel room. Edna is disturbing enough to give you “heebie jeebies”, but she gave Dr Watts a “Biology lesson”. She drugged and raped Dr Watts!!! WTF!!?? 12- The freakies You find them in the carnival, just take a look:  Skeleton man  Bearded Lady  Mermaid  Siamese Sisters (I’m not going to add Lightning & Zeke because I don’t want a BNBR for offending shorties)  Sorry for being too long 😅 EDIT: Thanks to Robert Burton for reminding me about the Freaks of the Carnival. By far the creepiest game that I’ve ever experienced is Petscop.  I doubt you’ve ever heard of it. And from looking at it, what could be so scary about it? It looks and sounds kinda cute, right?The thing is Petscop doesn’t exist. Or rather, no one can play it, as it is unavailable to anybody (save for Paul). The company that made it, Garalina, also don’t seem to exist. So if this game and game company don’t exist, how do I know about it?  A few months ago a YouTube channel named ‘Petscop’ uploaded videos about the game, with someone named Paul playing them. He started recording and uploading them initially for a friend to prove to them that the game is real. At first the game seems like a normal PS1 video game for kids, just like you probably thought at first.  It starts off like Pokémon, where you have to collect (or rather “catch”) these creatures just known as pets or gifts. Sounds innocent, I know. Except the way you have to catch them requires Paul to be deceptive and con the pets so that he can catch them. Amber is caught because she thought she was jumping to safety. Randice was caught because they thought they would get rain water, and Wavey was caught after they spent all their rain water in a bucket meant for Randice. Okay, so it’s subtly cruel and dark, not scary, so what’s the big deal? Paul later has to use a cheat code he found with the game, which ends up putting him into what we later know as the Newmaker Plane.  The area is mostly this desolate grassy place with some buildings every now and then, prominently a windmill or a shed or Michael’s grave.  Just from figuring out how old Michael was makes this seemingly child-friendly game much creepier. Also, the phrase ‘Mike was a gift’ questions the lack of regard the game has for children and pets; as an earlier sign stated, ‘When you’re choosing a pet, find somebody you like” instead “find one that you like” (which upon revisiting is what it changes to), as you’d expect it to say. The entire game continues to blur the idea of pets and adopted kids with the neglect many fostered kids face, which becomes a key theme to the entire series. Yeah, I know it’s not entirely creepy just yet, but I’ll cover one more thing this “game” has to offer out of the many theories and creepy moments the series has. One of the most widely accepted and popular theories among fans is the connection it has to Candace Newmaker. Now before anyone clicks on the link, I will warn you it is an extremely unpleasant story and you may find it quite disturbing. The game itself never makes any explicit references to the Newmaker incident, but there’s enough of them to not call it a coincidence.As I’ve already mentioned, the place Paul visits after the main area (the Gift Plane/Even Care) is the Newmaker Plane, which you will have spotted that connection already.   (The latter image says “QUITTER’S ROOM” on each side; backwards on the player’s side) (Again, discretion advised for the following paragraph) Now, if you didn’t click the link or didn’t already know about Candace Newmaker’s tragic death, you may not understand the context of the text box. Just to summarise it shortly she was a girl adopted by Jean Newmaker at around 10; Candace had her name changed from Candace Tiara Elmore to Candace Elizabeth Newmaker; and the two weren’t connecting very well. Jean found a supposed psychological treatment called “rebirthing” where psychologists would cover Candace in a blanket and sit on top of her with their combined weight crushing her, waiting for Candace to fight her way out in order to be “rebirthed” to her new mother so they can get attached easier. After fighting for around 40 minutes and Candace pleading for her life, the “psychologists” calling her a “quitter” and telling her to “die then”, she was eventually released and found turned blue, lying in her own vomit and brain dead. Candace Newmaker died the following day. So why would a gamemaker (revealed as Rainer later on, who eerily had some personal connection to Paul Christmas of 2000) make all these references to this tragic event? Well, as said before, Petscop sheds light on the neglect of children, prominently adopted children like Candace herself. The darker truth to all this is that stuff like this still happens. Many children are neglected all the time by parents and foster parents and in some extreme cases, this neglect results in death. The Candace Newmaker theory only scratches the surface of what is an even creepier game that has a real deep and personal connection to Paul himself the more he plays it, going so far as to actually censor some images out.  I highly recommend checking out the YouTube channel itself and the subreddit, which discusses theories around Petscop. Furthermore, I’d recommend watching theories of the game on YouTube itself if you want to know more about Petscop.

This is one I’ve been playing the last few days, and it’s disturbing in a wonderful way. It’s subtle. And it shocked me to my core. Deus Ex: Mankind Divided.  Background The franchise’s trope is that people can become augmented. In the originals, in the ‘90s, you were augmented with nanites, but the more recent games have been prequels, where you’re basically wearing prosthetics that turn you into a superhuman, like the Million Dollar Man. Depending what augs you invest in (and you can eventually get them ALL), you can have essentially whatever superpower you like: you have metal claws that come out of your arms, you’re invulnerable to bullets, invisible, stronger, faster-running, higher-jumping. You can fire things from your fists, you can affect people’s minds through pheromones to get them to agree with you, you have x-ray vision, you can hack any computer or security system, and so on and so forth. You can get all of these abilities, and you start with a bunch of them. You’re not just a superman. You are most of DC and Marvel's pantheon of superheroes and then some. But, because of something in a previous game that happened that caused augmented people (“augs”) to involuntarily kill people all over the world, augs in this world are seen as second-class citizens. Dangerous to “naturals”. Scary, and “less than human”. They have to take expensive drugs just to keep their bodies working, but they can’t get jobs. They are segregated and ghettoised.  Why it’s disturbing Well… it’s not. Initially. The game starts with a terrorist attack, apparently by augs, on a subway station. You try to help a little boy dig his mother out of the rubble. She’s already dead. You make your way around the game hub of Prague, solving little subquests. It’s cool, a sneak-’em-up. You don’t have to kill anyone (I haven’t, yet), as you’re ridiculously overpowered even in the early game, at high difficulty. You can go anywhere in the city: nothing can keep you out. But, to get around, there is a subway system. The carriages and the entry/exit passages are segregated. Naturals on one side, augs on the other. Naturals get the green sign, augs the red one.Naturals get three electronic turnstiles, augs get one manual one.Naturals get to walk in the open, augs are in some kind of confining cage.Naturals move in and out freely, while cops watch the Augs line, heaping insults on them as it moves slowly. But you have the right papers so can walk right past the line, and use the aug entrance just fine, no lining up.Naturals get to use the nearest part of the platform: augs are on the far end, having to walk past the naturals who talk about them and mock them.Naturals get to use the carriages at the front of the train, augs at the back.But you… you can use the naturals’ entrance just fine. And you can get on the naturals’ carriages. Nobody prevents you. But when you do so, in the cutscene as you ride it, a parent watches you worriedly, holding her child close. Are you one of the terrorists? And you know, you know, that with one keypress, you could fire out a whirlwind of bullets killing everyone in the carriage; that ability costs you just 2 “praxis points”. So her fear is not unjustified, and you know it: less than 12 game-hours prior, you were lifting rubble off a mother like her, as a boy like him cried, as an aug like you had killed them. Everyone in that city knows it. And when you get out of the carriage, a cop gives you grief, demands to see your papers. They check out, but he still gives you grief, something like: I give you credit that you don’t look stupid. So I can only assume you wanted to make a point. This is not the place. And he’s right. People are scared. You’re an aug. You could kill them. By being in their space, by violating their social rules, you’re threatening them. He’s right to give you shit about that. He doesn’t even detain you - just checks your papers. He’s doing his job. You hear that the papers they’ve recovered from the bombing are giving them clues. Of course he’s checking your papers. And if you take the natural’s path out of the station, you’ll get grief at the exit, again. Twice you get your papers checked, getting off the train and leaving the station. And you can’t, really, argue against that. But… the segregation isn’t right. You’re not lesser. Those other augs, using the aug carriage. They’re not lesser. They’re people too. It’s unjust. It’s wrong. And that’s when it gets disturbing. Because, that hassling. It eventually gets to you. Not in a big way. It’s just… inconvenient. Even though he’s just doing his job, you could kill that one guard, or knock him out, hide the body in a store-room… but still, every time you travel to a new location, there’ll maybe be some other guard. You could get rid of them all, so that it‘d be just as fast and hassle-free for you to travel on the naturals’ side, as on the augs’ side. But there’d still be that young mother, looking at you out of the side of her eye, casually interposing her body between her son and you, incase you explode in a fireball of death. At first, I did use the naturals’ carriage. They were in the wrong. The segregation was wrong. But the cop was right. Who was I making a point to? To these cops? To the other passengers? To the un-thinking AI in my computer game? I’ve always prided myself as being the one who would say “no” in the Milgram experiment. I often buck authority where I see it as immoral. But, eventually, I got bored of all the “papers, please” nonsense, and I’d avoid the subway as a means of transit. I’d just walk, instead. That was mostly unconscious, but I eventually realized I was doing it. I’d walk across the city, essentially self-segregating, to avoid the segregation. But there’s a river, where the subway is the only way to cross, and for that I’d use the segregated turnstile and carriage. It was a conscious choice, which meant accepting being treated as a second class citizen. Being mocked both openly and in whispers behind my back. But I rationalized it to myself. I had a job to do, and it’s less hassle to not be the nail that sticks up. I’m meant to be a stealth operative, I don’t need to draw attention to myself. I’m fighting the system in other ways. I don’t need to upset people just to feel good about myself… and so on. Knowing that I was doing it, but seeing no faster way to move around the city and do what I needed to, I rationalized and internalized my character’s place as a second-class being in this world. Because it meant less inconvenience. And then, just after I stepped onto a carriage, to a station I knew would be deserted, with no guards checking who stepped off from which carriage, I realized that I had still obediently walked the whole length of the platform, and boarded the augs’ carriage. That’s the most disturbing moment I have ever had in gaming. That’s wonderfully, gloriously, deeply disturbing. That’s the kind of morality exploration I’ve been hoping for in gaming for decades. It’s subtle, and so I’ve been unable to explain to people why it was such a “wow” moment for me. I’d walked into that situation with open, self-reflective eyes, thinking about my decisions and wondering what was morally best, and it had still caught me. Would I, in the beginnings of Nazi Germany, have stood up against the authorities as they began to segregate people? Would I, if I were Jewish, refused to have worn the star? Or would I have done what they told me, have gone along with everything, just because it was less inconvenient? I hope you, dear reader, can understand why I rank this game as the most disturbing I’ve ever played.

Seeing as no one has mentioned it yet, I’d say that a game that is morally disturbing is Grand Theft Auto. All the things that we do in GTA, we would be absolutely horrified to see it in real life. It’s the type of stuff that drug cartels and groups like ISIS do. When I saw the Vegas shooting, and how he just shot into a crowd without any sort of significant motivation, no manifesto, no goal, almost as if he was bored and wanted to go out with a bang, I was reminded of the massacres we always participate in, in GTA. Those massacres are without any real motivation, they’re just for fun. And I thought, in the in-game universe of GTA, technically the aftermath of our casual massacres would look just like it did with Vegas. Another recent event was when the Cleveland shooter shot that poor guy in the head on a facebook stream. It was horrifying, he just randomly and casually shot him in the head. It’s just like GTA, where we just kill random pedestrians on the street. Of course GTA is virtual, but it does give us the capacity to commit actions, that would be considered atrocities in real life, in a virtually simulated environment. I find this incredibly interesting. It means that although we’re horrified by such atrocities if they were to happen in real life, we’re OK with simulating them in virtual environments, which means a part of us is fascinated, on some level, with such violence. Not only that, but it potentially puts us in the mindset of a real killer. From a GTA perspective, players usually treat the NPCs as nothing of note, they don’t think much about the NPCs. Maybe this is the way that real killers view the world. Maybe that’s how people like cartels soldiers can commit heinous acts without a care in the world. They don’t feel any empathy for their victims in the same way that you don’t feel anything when you put a bullet in a random NPC.  Rarely does a game allow you to use flamethrowers on a civilian populace, use mini guns to wreck utter carnage, cut people up with chainsaws, run over civilians, crush people with tanks, etc. GTA allows us to execute heinous acts on virtual people. You can simulate mass shootings, fly planes into buildings, etc. I love Grand Theft Auto, it’s one of my favorite games and this element of disturbing morals is a big part of why I play. I have the freedom to help virtual people or I have the freedom to destroy them. It’s a great platform to engage in role playing, GTA gives you the freedom to roleplay almost anything in a modern day setting, all you need is imagination.

Weird Dreams on the Amiga. Not a particularly disturbing (or good) game as released. But - its original plot was so upsetting that it had to be changed before release.  The original plot? You are having surgery and are placed under general anesthetic. However, you find yourself having nightmares. If things go too wrong in the nightmare, your heart rate will speed up, overcome the anesthesia, and you will wake up..  … and get to experience surgery while awake. You can probably guess why that had to be changed. It didn’t help that failed anesthesia was actually an issue in real hospitals at the time (which is probably what inspired the plot). The changed plot fudged things somewhat by saying you were in hospital having an alien spore cut out of your brain, and that was why it was giving you nightmares. The game over screen showed the scene above, but with the EEG flatlining indicating you had died - whereas the original one showed one of the surgeons lowering a scalpel towards you. So death was the less upsetting ending. But, with the extra attention paid to this question, I’ve been thinking.. does disturbing have to mean scary? Well, if it does for you, you can stop reading here, but there were one or two games which I found very unsettling but in a positive way.  At first glance this game is a simple physics toy. You drag fire around on the end of the mouse, and you can create items to burn which react to being burned in different ways. When you burn them, you get coins with which you can buy other things to burn. You gradually start to get missions and combo puzzles to complete. Where things start to get weird is when you start getting contacts from other characters, and suddenly realize that this physics toy has an entire world and setting. It’s been snowing for as long as anyone can remember, so now, all that everyone is told to do is to stay warm by gradually burning everything available. That’s kind of creepy to start with, but it gets more positively disturbing when you complete the main part of the game.. and at that point the fireplace breaks apart and the game turns into a point and click adventure in which you can walk around the world that you were previously only hearing about. Amongst other things, you can meet the mailman. Yea, the mailman who was delivering all the items you ordered with the game coins. He dropped them off to you without you ever turning around, and watched as you threw each one in the fire.. Second up in this category:  So, this is a rather odd game about creativity. The game opens with the game’s author - who addresses you by his real name, Davey, throughout - claiming that it’s a collection of games written by a friend of his whose games he admired. As you pass through the games, they get increasingly odd, the commentary gets more and more distant, and there’s gradually evidence of the friend - Coda - having some kind of breakdown which was showing up in the games. And then you get to the final game and it has an insulting message from Coda to Davey. Coda specifically told him not to share his games with others. Well, let’s see… (Note: spoilers for the selected game and notifying that I’ve crossed 2 million views, which I see as an absolute win! So, my greatest gratitude). Without further ado, here’s my pick for one of the most disturbing video games ever made: Call of Duty: World at War.  Now yes, Call of Duty has brushed with disturbing moments with its campaigns (No Russian, anyone?), but as a whole package, World at War is an undisputedly unsettling demon of a video game. The backstory for the Nazi Zombies mode, set to blast off above and beyond with its later sequel in Black Ops, is brimming with disturbing material, too. But to keep it short(er), I’ll focus on the game’s main campaign. And quite honestly, where do I even begin?  https://youtu.be/6bcsXeuK8kk The link above is to the game’s main menu theme. The title is “Braff Soldat.” Brave Soldier. Here are the lyrics: Braff Soldat. (Brave Soldier) Braff Soldat. (Brave Soldier) Stirb mit mir. (Die with me) Stirb mit mir. (Die with me) Stirb mit mir. (Die with me) Braff Soldat. (Brave Soldier) Hier Nacht (Here tonight). The lyrics are underscored by some of the hauntingly unsettling vocals and almost pained wailing, letting you know from the outset that this game… isn’t what you think it might be. The soundtrack for this game is incredible as well. Not one track feels triumphant or empowering (save for arguably the Soviet theme that plays as you get to the very top of the Reichstag). Every track has a underlying link to tragedy, with the Black Cats theme especially being one of the most heart-pounding soundtracks in a video game. The music accentuates the fast-paced gameplay and adds another layer to the horrors of war that the game wishes to portray. —————————————————————————————— World at War’s campaign’s greatest strength is its utterly horrible and unflinching resolve to portray the events of World War 2 with no restraints. Treyarch could not care less about any gamer’s feelings (something Sledgehammer conveniently forgot to do with their own WW2 instalment) with its depiction of the Second World War.  You ever heard of an author called Tim O’Brien? He’s widely known for a book called The Things They Carried. I’ll share with you an immensely important quote that underlines why World at War’s ability to be unapologetic in its depiction of the most infamous conflict in our history is so disturbingly powerful. Here’s the quote: “A true war story is never moral. It does not instruct, nor encourage virtue, nor suggest models of proper human behaviour, nor restrain men from doing the things men have always done. If a story seems moral, do not believe it. If at the end of a war story you feel uplifted, or if you feel that some small bit of rectitude has been salvaged, then you have been made the victim of a very old and terrible lie. There is no rectitude whatsoever. There is no virtue. As a first rule of thumb, therefore, you can tell a true war story by its absolute and uncompromising allegiance to obscenity and evil.” When a game developer, author or film director wants to make a story surrounding war, this means they should have no reservations about what they’re trying to depict. If you’re going to tell a war story, you need the guts to portray it without any obstruction from morality or virtue. Both of these qualities are absent in war. Obviously, the quote above doesn’t apply to every war story, fiction or non, and it is arguable I’m not using it in the correct context, but my justification for this quotes inclusion is to highlight the difference between what feels more authentic and what feels more Hollywood.  The greatest flaw with Call of Duty: WWII’s storyline is its inability to be absolute and uncompromising in its allegiance to obscenity and evil. Yes, I thought Daniels was a decent protagonist. I thought his dynamics with his squadmates, notably Zussman, Pierson and Turner, was tangible. Yes, there was strong violence and depictions of war crimes. But the setting of Americans fighting against the Germans is just so generic. It’s been done to death in film and gaming. The Second World War is infamous in its scope as well as its brutality. Nearly every country in the world was involved in some fashion. This game’s storyline is too binary in its depiction of the Americans and its allies as the force of good versus the Germans as the absolute evil. The censorship of the swastika (save for occasional inclusions) is what bugs me the most. Yes, it’s controversial, but it’s historically accurate and should be treated as such. The writers behind WWII were too afraid (owing to the real world socio-political climate of everyone being a little bitch) to depict the controversies that are typical and integral to the Second World War.  Conversely, such real world worries were toned down in 2008. World at War’s tone throughout the game is significantly serious. The light-heartedness and comic relief as shown in WWII is ditched in favour of driving home a dark and uncomfortable atmosphere. WWII’s campaign, aside from giving us the traditional and annoyingly exaggerated Call of Duty action flair the series is known for (like with the Panzerzug train wreck that took 30 seconds to finally stop crashing), is safe, upbeat and positive. That’s good to keep up morale, cracking wise and making the best out of an otherwise depressingly desperate situation. But it doesn’t feel as authentic as it could have been. I feel like I’m playing a glorified shoot-’em-up that makes you feel ‘happy’ about being a soldier on the front lines of the most horrifying war ever. —————————————————————————————— So, to further illustrate why World at War is worthy of being recognised for the disturbing content it depicts, I’ll outline more specific examples. The campaign shifts between two fronts and two perspectives. You have Pvt. Miller in the Marine Corps fighting against the Imperial Japanese in the Pacific Theatre. Then there is Dimitri Petrenko, fighting alongside Viktor Reznov and the Red Army as they push from Stalingrad to the top of the Reichstag on the Eastern Front. The most noticeable quality expressive of the game’s unsettling nature is the graphic violence.    Even for 2008, it’s disgustingly visceral. There is a variety of weapons in the game which allows for this mechanic (‘gibbing’) to occur quite frequently, namely the MG42, PTRS-41, M1987 Trench Gun, Type 91, Panzerschreck, and mortars. Guns that blast off an arm or even both legs of an enemy soldier sends him on his back, clutching at the lost limb in shrieking agony. Molotov’s and flamethrowers make the enemy NPCs scream and howl in piercingly unnerving yells as their skin ignites and their flesh is roasted. It enhances the experience because it unsettles the player, and does not feel exaggerated or gratuitous because it is very much in line with World at War’s atmosphere.  Driving around in a tank on the level Blood and Iron, for instance, allows a play to crush Germans beneath their treads, and the sickening crunches of bones being grounded to power is awful. The horror doesn’t stop there. It extends to the unique encounters in the gameplay and storylines.  For example, with the Japanese, it would very boring if you ran through each mission and just shot at them hiding in cover. But they use the locations and tactics of the time to create equally interesting and brutal gameplay. They don’t just move forward and shoot from behind cover. They sprint forward with a cry of “TENNOHAIKA BANZAIIIII!” (May the Emperor live for ten thousand years!) and try to impale you with their bayonets. They kamikaze their planes into warships, play dead, set traps for ambushes (which an unsuspecting Marine can’t counter if they’re caught), rise out of the grass wearing ghillie suits, pop up from spider holes and snipe from atop trees. These twists and turns serving to surprise the player adds to the authenticity that the Japanese were efficient and ruthless, showing no mercy in their attempts to outsmart the Americans. And the Marines aren’t shying away from relishing in their small victories. A fellow Marine called Polonsky shouts “Hell yeah! Burn, ya little bastards!” when clearing out a bunker, Sergeant Sullivan orders you to “Get on those MGs and tear them up!”, and a random Marine in the first level repeatedly shoots a Japanese officer in the chest, shouting “You like that, you piece of shit?!” On the other side with the Eastern Front, there is more emphasis on the story and characters, and how they are influenced by the same horrors of war that the game wishes to share with you. Petrenko starts at a fountain in Red Square, just recovering from a bloody massacre of dozens of his comrades.  The German soldier above then shoots a couple of survivors in cold blood, and as you crawl around with Reznov, the blood of each man is plastered across the ground and the walls as they lay face down on the concrete or stare at the sky with empty eyes. Then, as we progress further into the heart of Germany, the plot thickens. The player is able to imagine and experience what fighting on those fronts with those soldiers would be like. You dive deep into the Russian’s perspective of the war and the Germans. It’s nothing short of vengeful and barbaric. Reznov: Dimitri? Finish those rats! Hahaha, once again, you cheat death. Our tanks are ready to smash this line and… CHERNOV! I’m not hearing gunshots. Chernov: There is no point, Sergeant. They’re already bleeding to death. Reznov: Then maybe our friend will help them bleed faster. (Their Land, Their Blood) Moments like these show another one of the game’s strengths in its disturbing content: objectivity. The game does not romanticise the war. It doesn’t really matter if you root for the Soviets or the Americans, all the game wants to achieve is the depiction of these battles in the most grounded and brutal way it can. Every side is neither absolutely good or bad. The Americans and Japanese are equal in their brutal tactics on one another and the Soviets and Germans are as merciless as they can be with their atrocities. Reznov and the other Russians get more and more bloodthirsty as you progress further into the heart of Germany. Soldiers like Chernov wonder if all this conflict and slaughter is worth it. It progresses to infighting in some instances:  In the level Eviction, Dimitri and Reznov make to move out of a building where they come across a German soldier on his knees pleading for mercy. This is the dialogue from his comrades: “He wants mercy!” “You do not (slaps German) DESERVE mercy!” “What mercy did you show to our people?!” “Time to die!” “Wait, wait! He may help us -” “’Help’ us?! He can DIE for us!” (Shoots German) You as the player understand that you are fighting to end the Nazi’s regime and end the war, but it doesn’t excuse what the Soviets did to achieve that. Murdering surrendered soldiers in cold blood, marching Wehrmacht to a firing line to be executed, it’s awful. This gives the story on the Eastern Front a dramatic dimension to it, of how war reduces us to our basest senses. Reznov is proof of that. Reznov: (to Chernov) What do you think will lead us home? (Snatches diary) Writing about this war or fighting it?! (Pulls up Chernov and slaps his diary back) No one will ever read this! If you lack the stomach to kill for your country, at least show me that you’re willing to die for it!” (Gives Chernov the Soviet flag) (Heart of the Reich) Then later in the same level, as you get to the entrance of the Reichstag, Chernov is burned alive by a German flamethrower, and Reznov recovers his diary. “Dimitri! Someone should read this…”  —————————————————————————————— And after you’ve planted the Soviet flag atop the Reichstag, after all of the depraved and depressing carnage you’ve slogged through, you are shown footage in an epilogue of sorts. It depicts the readying and deployment of the atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki to end the war in the Pacific Theatre. Harry Truman: General Eisenhower informs me that the forces of Germany have surrendered to the United Nations. The victory won in the West must now be won in the East. Afterwards, we see General MacArthur address the representatives present to the Japanese’s declaration of surrender, where excerpts from his speech are given: General MacArthur: We are gathered here, representatives of the major warring powers, to conclude a solemn agreement, whereby peace may be restored. It is my earnest hope, and indeed the hope of all mankind, that from this solemn occasion, a better world shall emerge out of the blood and carnage of the past. A world founded upon faith and understanding, of man and the fulfilment of his most cherished wish, of freedom, tolerance and justice. Then the game reminds you what it was all about. “60 million lives were lost as a result of World War II. It was the most destructive and deadly conflict in human history.” Call of Duty: WWII made the mistake of showing this message at the beginning, where its power is given greater strength when placed at the end. It encourages you to reflect. One tenth of those casualties can be attributed to the Jewish population killed in the Holocaust, pushing nearly a third if we include all the other minorities. This gives games set in historical periods as infamous as this an edge because it happened in our lifetime, and reshaped the political, technological, social, geographical and ideological landscape of today. I don’t feel awesome or proud when playing the campaign. I feel… uncomfortable. Conflicted. It’s morally corrupt. I’m grateful that such a game like World at War exists, because it serves as a dedication to all those lives lost for the preservation of the liberties we take for granted nearly 75 years later. We use history and conflicts like World War 2 to look to the past in order to act on things in the present to make a better future for the next generation.  Does this mean the game isn’t fun to play? Of course not! That’s where I derive the enjoyment from in the campaign. I take the campaign’s subject matter seriously and the game doesn’t insult my intelligence. In its objective, honest and authentic depiction of the call to duty these soldiers had to make, World at War’s story feels that much more compelling than most other shooters and World War 2 games. It also harkens back to when Call of Duty had soul, no franchise fatigue in sight, and revelling in its rise to power. Yet, in my analysis of its absolute and uncompromising allegiance to obscenity and evil, World at War’s is one of the most disturbing games you will ever lay your hands on. Peace and Love. A short life and a merry one.

In the deep, dark recesses of indie gore games, there’s one that dials the horror up so far it doesn’t even need audio. The saving grace is that it’s so obscure and unknown that few, if any people have played it. Word of warning: it’s strictly for adults, very amateurish in its production, and extremely gruesome. There are major spoilers ahead. I’m going to skip over all the horrible gore, because that’s not even 20% of what makes this game disturbing. I really, absolutely, definitely do not recommend playing this game unless if you are dead certain on not sleeping for the next week. The content warnings alone should make this game Adults Only and A Really Bad Idea For A Relaxing Weekend. No seriously, run away. Now. Only the insane shall continue on.  Demonophobia  Enter Sakuri. You have no idea what she’s doing in this weird stony corridor. She doesn’t either. Hell, there’s so little explanation, you as the player will have to mash keys until you figure out her basic commands - move, crouch, use/pick up, sprint. Though that last one is very short-lived; Sakuri certainly didn’t have good grades in P.E. Yes, there’s also no audio, not even sound effects. On one hand you’ll be glad for it. On the other, that means no audio feedback, which means that things become that much more unknowable and creepy. You’ll notice that there’s no weapon. She can’t throw any punches. There’s not even an examine. But there certainly are enemies and traps, many instantly lethal. When you die, you can press R to respawn. Good, at least the game tells you that. Each level gets progressively creepier. The enemies are already disturbing, the traps ever more lethal and gory, the bosses increasingly terrifying.  No seriously, this is tame compared to the later ones. And they match up to certain themes, like the Seven Deadly Sins. Early on, someone gives pity on this poor soul and comes in to advise and aid her. Enter Ritz, the floating, ominous spirit thing who at least doesn’t look like animated, jagged flesh like all the other creatures.  Through the game, you die. A lot. It’s a level memorization game where Sakuri’s options are to run or hide from enemies. With Ritz’s help, she can find certain objects in each level that let her defeat the boss of the floor instead of running away like the previous two. The only thing getting Sakuri through Hell is Ritz’s words of “encouragement” and the promise of escape. Ritz of course is pulling a fast one. He’s using Sakuri to get past the guardians and leaving this place by sacrificing her. After a gauntlet of some truly disturbing levels, including one where her house and family have been warped into Hell and assimilated into its insanity, she’s had it. Doing the impossible, she destroys Ritz. In his last dying breaths, he reveals that no one in Hell can die or escape. Not even him. He was acting on delusions, hoping that doing something so cruel could get him out. Maybe if the universe ended they’d be released, he ponders. As he disappears from view, memories start flooding into Sakuri’s mind, ones that Ritz had been blocking with his magic. It turns out that each time that “R” button was pushed, Ritz had painstakingly put the remains of Sakuri back together. Making her forget about her deaths was his salvation to her. And now that she’d rejected it?  The final lines of the game: I don’t know how long I have been here. Where on earth is this? Why am I in this sort of place?! Who’s there? You, over here, who are you? No need to fear… I want to save you. It’s not just the body horror. It’s not just the eternity of damnation. It’s the hopelessness, the slide into insanity. You’re there on the precipice and the end harkens the moment you fall off. Your imagination can do the rest. And when you realize that the ever-observant shadows in the background quite possibly represents us, the players? That we are the ones responsible for the rules of this hellhole of suffering? I did not sleep well that night.  You can download it here legally (it’s open source). If you prefer a more let’s play version, read through this walkthrough - it makes it easier to retain one’s sanity.

I'll suggest one that is well-written and is creepy for two important reasons. The first reason is the content itself: heavily inspired by Lovecraft, but with themes of incest and other dark family history mixed in. The second is that it's a text adventure game, so the lack of graphics or sound allows your own imagination to get the better of you as you're reading through. The game is called Anchorhead. You can purchase the “Director's Cut" on Steam, which does include sporadic illustrations, or you can find an interpreter for your device and download the original version at no cost. What makes this game so unsettling is the way the horror elements creep in. It does have some shock horror, but it's not limited to that. Sometimes it's the fear of discovery while hiding or eavesdropping. Other times, it's the feeling you get when you read a diary entry and wish you hadn't. The story begins with a melancholy backdrop. You play as a newlywed woman whose husband inherited a mansion in a little coastal town in New England. Sounds great, except you've lived in Texas your whole life, and you weren't planning on this kind of uprooting. Also, the whole town is hopelessly backwater and ugly, and the weather is dreary, all the more so because it's November. You have just arrived at the Real Estate agent's office, where you are supposed to pick up your house keys and go to your new home. Your husband dropped you off and went to go study at the local university. Now you're alone outside, and wondering why the office is locked and the agent isn't showing up. That's where the game begins. As you unravel the mystery, the plot just keeps growing more sinister. You'll learn about the the history of the town and its founder, all the way up and down the family tree. You'll meet people who will die to keep the town's secrets, secret. There will be places where you'll narrowly escape death or capture. Before it's over, you'll encounter monsters so hideous, you'll lose your marbles if you look directly at them. If it sounds interesting but solving puzzles in text adventure games is something you'd rather leave to the Zork junkies, don't despair. I put together a fan-based “Guided Tour" for your help and further enjoyment of the story. Enjoy.

I have seen some good suggestions already in this thread, among them are Spec Ops: The Line, This War of Mine, Doki Doki Literature Club, and Silent Hill 2. But many of the other games like Manhunt, Hatred, and Outlast are not (in my opinion) disturbing so much as shocking or frightening. To me, a game that is disturbing has to have moments of realization, or reveal, like a good magic trick. Disturbing games need to have a building of awareness about the horror you’re facing. Without spoiling too much, all three of the above bolded games has a slow reveal of how horrifying the situation of the character truly is, and the player is forced to slowly come to terms with that horror. With that definition established, here are some of the most disturbing games I have ever played that most people aren’t mentioning. All of the following are available on Steam or the Humble Store, and most are available on GoG  A Wolf in Autumn, Fingerbones, The Moon Sliver, The Music MachineThese four games, by the same single developer (David Szymanski), are extremely disturbing. Szymanski focuses his game creation on making emotionally impactful and narratively focused horror, and does it extremely well. The Moon Sliver is technically a prequel to The Music Machine, but you can play them in whatever order you want. The experience of playing each is hard to describe, but A Wolf in Autumn is about the experience of being trapped in an abusive situation, and the three others are about uncovering mysteries in very foreign worlds. They are well worth their (quite cheap) prices, and I highly recommend all of them.Fran BowFran Bow is a story about a young, mentally ill girl on a quest to return to her family with the help of her cat. Her journey is extremely strange, and disorienting to the player, and Fran. I actually have not finished it yet, as some of the puzzles can be quite complex, but it has been quite an experience so far.Lone SurvivorOriginally created as a pixel-graphics tribute to Silent Hill, Lone Survivor is a delightfully disturbing game all on its own, and one of my favorites. Your character is a survivor of some deadly disease that has ravaged his apartment complex, and the rest of the world. He must survive and find other survivors, but his isolation is steadily driving him mad and as the player, less and less of what you see and think you know about the world can be trusted as you progress.Knock-KnockKnock-Knock is a very strange game by Ice-Pick Lodge with very simple gameplay. It is not hard to beat, but it is extremely uncomfortable to play (I highly recommend headphones for the full experience, don’t worry there are no jumpscares). You spend your sleepless nights wandering your house looking for the sources of noises, but awake in the forest outside every morning, and every night when the noises return, the house is a bit different than the last time you awoke.Everybody’s Gone to the RaptureIn this game, you play a person who explores a small English village where an astronomical phenomenon has caused everyone to disappear. All that is left behind are people’s belongings, and strange echoes of the last moments and encounters of the people in the village. It is a very disturbing experience walking through such an empty place listening to the last life that existed there.Pony IslandI can’t tell you much about this game without spoiling the surprises in it, but I highly recommend it, I think it’s very fun to play and well designed, and it’s a bit more light-hearted than the other entries on my listHonorable mentions:These are games that are very disturbing, but for one reason or another I cannot recommend. Most of the time, I can’t recommend them because they are extremely confusing and overwhelming to new players looking for a purely disturbing experience. Others I simply haven’t played yet, but look very promising.PathologicThe VoidThe GrandfatherThe Cat LadyUncanny Valley Thanks for reading, I hope you enjoy my recommendations!
